title: 113_hr2858
content: The Act is titled the "Wildland Firefighters Protection Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Wildland Firefighters Protection Act" defines a wildland firefighter as an employee of a Federal land management agency primarily involved in wildfire prevention and management. Federal land management agencies include the Bureau of Land Management and the Bureau of Indian Affairs within the Department of the Interior. The term "employee" as defined by the "Wildland Firefighters Protection Act" refers to individuals working for Federal land management agencies such as the Bureau of Land Management, Bureau of Indian Affairs, National Park Service, Fish and Wildlife Service, and Forest Service. SEC. 3. CLASSIFICATION OF WILDLAND FIREFIGHTERS. Within 30 days of this Act's enactment, the Office of Personnel Management will work with Federal land management agencies to create a new wildland firefighter occupational series. The official title for this series will be "Wildland Firefighter" and will cover positions such as forestry technicians and range technicians. The duties of the new Wildland Firefighter occupational series include significant wildfire preparedness and suppression activities, as well as activities for other emergency incidents. Congress encourages consultation with employee organizations representing Federal wildland firefighters. This does not affect the Hazardous Duty Differential for employees in the wildland firefighting occupational series. Employees currently in the 401 series who are wildland firefighters have the option to remain in the current series or be included in the new wildland firefighter series established by the Office. The new wildland firefighter series established by the Office includes pay and benefits. The new wildland firefighter series established by the Office includes a Portal-to-Portal Compensation Pilot Program for overtime work during emergency incidents. The portal-to-portal compensation pilot program for wildland firefighters during emergency incidents includes amending title 5 of the United States Code and the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to provide overtime pay at one and a half times the hourly rate as premium pay. The pilot program for wildland firefighters under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 allows for premium pay and exempts violations if program requirements are met. The program will be conducted by the Department of the Interior and Agriculture for a maximum of 3 years starting from the 2014 wildfire season. The Fair Labor Standards Act pilot program for wildland firefighters allows for premium pay and exempts violations. Funding will be provided from the FLAME Wildfire Suppression Reserve Funds for the program. The pilot program for wildland firefighters includes premium pay and exempts violations. The program will be funded from the FLAME Wildfire Suppression Reserve Funds. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture must submit a report within 90 days after the program's completion. The pilot program for wildland firefighters includes premium pay exemptions and a joint report to Congress on its effectiveness. Employees under the program are exempt from premium pay limitations. In amendments to the code, subparagraphs were adjusted and a new subparagraph (I) was added regarding pay differentials for wildland firefighters. Additionally, a conforming amendment was made to section 8331(3). In the administration of hazardous duty differentials under section 5545(d), certain provisions apply. In the administration of section 5545(d) of title 5, United States Code, the Office of Personnel Management ensures a 25 percent pay differential for individuals serving on wildland firefighting crews, including ground and airborne personnel. Any individual subject to the Federal Employees' Retirement System as a firefighter on the date of the enactment of this Act is entitled to have qualifying firefighter service treated as creditable service. Qualifying firefighter service refers to service performed as a wildland firefighter after 1989 and before the date of the enactment of this Act. Any firefighter under the Federal Employees' Retirement System can receive credit for qualifying firefighter service performed after 1989. To receive credit, the individual must make a deposit equal to employee contributions required for that period. The Office of Personnel Management will accept certification from the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture regarding qualifying firefighter service. The length of the period of qualifying firefighter service performed by an individual is important for determining eligibility.
